title: Migration:generate issue with onUpdate using mysql 8.0
body:
**Issue type:**

[ ] question
[x] bug report
[ ] feature request
[ ] documentation issue

**Database system/driver:**

[ ] `cordova`
[ ] `mongodb`
[ ] `mssql`
[x] `mysql` / `mariadb`
[ ] `oracle`
[ ] `postgres`
[ ] `sqlite`
[ ] `sqljs`
[ ] `react-native`
[ ] `expo`

**TypeORM version:**

[x] `latest`
[ ] `@next`
[ ] `0.x.x` (or put your version here)

**Steps to reproduce or a small repository showing the problem:**

A column with onUpdate
``` 
@Column({
    name: 'updated_at',
    type: 'timestamp',
    precision: 3,
    nullable: false,
    default: () => 'CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)',
    onUpdate: 'CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)',
  })
```

will generate migrations over and over again because the database column schema doesn't match the typeORM model.

The latest version of mysql is now adding a DEFAULT_GENERATED tag when a default is explicitly set
https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/show-columns.html

EXTRA column value 
```
DEFAULT_GENERATED on update CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)
```

this results in a the following erroneous generated migration:
```
  upQueries:
   [ 'ALTER TABLE `approvals_approval` CHANGE `updated_at` `updated_at` timestamp(3) NOT NULL DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3) ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)',
     'ALTER TABLE `approvals_approval_type` CHANGE `updated_at` `updated_at` timestamp(3) NOT NULL DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3) ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)' ],
  downQueries:
   [ 'ALTER TABLE `approvals_approval` CHANGE `updated_at` `updated_at` timestamp(3) NOT NULL DEFAULT \'CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)\' ON UPDATE NERATED on update CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)',
     'ALTER TABLE `approvals_approval_type` CHANGE `updated_at` `updated_at` timestamp(3) NOT NULL DEFAULT \'CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)\' ON UPDATE NERATED on update CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)' ] }
```

This bug is due to a hard-coded assumption in `MysqlQueryRunner.ts` which assumes that `on update` command will be the only item in the EXTRA string.

```
                    if (dbColumn["EXTRA"].indexOf("on update") !== -1) {
                        tableColumn.onUpdate = dbColumn["EXTRA"].substring(10);
                    }
```

now need to account for the starting index of the `on update` when taking the substring or find the value associated with the on update in a more robust manner.
